post_text: We are so grateful to our surrounding community. You guys stepped up to help our neighbors in need. We appreciated all the donations and now, we are partnering with the Santiam Integration Team. Donations can now be dropped off at Anthony Hall in Sublimity. Also, our friends at Stayton High School gathered items at Foothills Church in Stayton starting Wednesday 9-12 and 1-4.Thank you!

post_text: While we regretfully had to postpone the start of the school year, we did so because the state requires we serve meals every single school day even during distance learning. Because of COVID, we distribute meals in a drive-thru style. We could not risk our staff standing outside or families picking up meals in these hazardous air conditions.

post_text: Due to the hazardous air quality, we are canceling school for the rest of this week. The first day of school will now be Monday, September 21. While it was our hope that we could begin distance learning this week, the extremely dangerous air quality puts the safety of our staff at risk. Thank you for your understanding.

post_text:
Due to the overwhelming generosity of the Cascade community, we have more clothes and toys than expected. We know that many of our communities have been impacted by COVID and now the fires and we are here for you. ANYONE THAT NEEDS CLOTHES AND TOYS can come to Cascade until 3 today and get what you need. We have tons of baby's, kid's, women's, and men's clothing, and lots of shoes.

Also, we are partnering with the Santiam Integration Team. With teaching staff returning to school tomorrow, WE CAN NO LONGER ACCEPT DONATIONS AT CASCADE HIGH SCHOOL. Instead, please bring donations to Anthony Hall in Sublimity. They are accepting gently used items. Thank you!

Due to the fires and hazardous air conditions, we are postponing the start of the school year for both students and staff until Wednesday, September 16. Our thoughts and prayers stay with those who have been impacted by the fires.

Please visit the Wildfire Resources (https://bit.ly/CSDFireResources) section on our website for information and resources regarding the wildfires.

post_text:
Thank you so much for supporting Cascade Cares! We know how much you want to give. Unfortunately, we cannot accept any more clothes or stuffed animals at this time. Although we are in need of men's work clothes. We would also be happy to accept the following items: sleeping bags, sleeping pads, household items, non-perishable food items, laundry and dish detergent, work socks for those fighting the fires, bottled water, blankets, towels, hairbrushes
plastic cutlery, paper towels, paper plates.

Donations can be brought to the high school today (Sept 13) from 10-5. Or any day this week from 9-3. Also, anyone impacted by the fires can come to the high school today or any day this week to pick up whatever you may need. We are also able to put boxes together for people who can not make it to the school. Please email liverson@cascade.k12.or.us if you need anything!

Alright Cascade, this is amazing! Cascade High School will be open tomorrow (Sept. 12) and Sunday (Sept. 13) from 10-2 for anyone impacted by the fires to come pick up clothes, household items, food, toys, etc. If you know of anyone who needs anything, please tell them to come to Cascade High School. Please share this with your friends and neighbors, we are here for you!

We are also accepting items like hygiene products, pet supplies, baby wipes, lotion, household items, water, and cleaning supplies. At this point, we have plenty of clothing items and we appreciate everyone’s support. CASCADE STRONG!!

post_text: If you have clothing, household goods, non-perishable food, hygiene products, toys, sporting goods, or anything at all to donate to those impacted by the fires, please drop off at the Cascade High School main office on Friday, September 11, from 12-4 and every day next week from 7:30-3:30. Cascade student groups will help sort and distribute to those directly impacted by the fire. Firefighters need gatorade, snacks, Chapstick, baby wipes, eye drops, energy bars, and snacks can also be dropped off and we will make sure it gets to our firefighters up the Canyon. Together we are Cascade Strong!

Cascade student groups will help sort and distribute to those directly impacted by the fire. Firefighters need gatorade, snacks, Chapstick, baby wipes, eye drops, energy bars, and snacks can also be dropped off and we will make sure it gets to our firefighters up the Canyon. Together we are Cascade Strong!

post_text: Information resources! Please stay safe and informed. Our thoughts and prayers are with everyone affected by the fires
shared_text:
Metcom 911
September 10 at 1:48 PM ·

**SANTIAM FIRE UPDATE Thursday AM (9/10)**

No changes have been made to evacuation levels in Marion County.

We recognize there has been some confusion with alerts received on cell phones and evacuation level information. Please know that there are multiple counties involved in these fires which mean different evacuation levels and different methods of citizen notifications. This is beyond our control. We encourage citizens within OUR service area to sign up for Everbridge via our website at www.Metcom911.com (City of Salem residents sign up @ https://tinyurl.com/yxk2m5uy)

For evacuation levels, use the map for the county that you live in:
MARION COUNTY EVACUATION MAP:
http://bit.ly/MCEvacZones

CLACKAMAS COUNTY EVACUATION MAP:
https://ccgis-mapservice.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=fe0525732f1a4f679b75a5ccf1c84b30

LINN COUNTY EVACUATION MAP:
https://linngis.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=348a6e7fc2ab458293679f2b736dc676

Additionally, the incident management team for the Santiam Fire/Beachie Creek Fire has created a Facebook Page for this incident as well as a fire information line
FB Page: https://m.facebook.com/BeachieCreekFire2020/
Fire Information Line: 541-583-0526

Thank you to everyone who has been following our social media and sharing our information. Public safety and disseminating accurate information is our #1 goal.

Beachie Creek Fire Linn County Sheriff's Office Marion County Sheriff's Office Clackamas County Sheriff's Office Willamette Valley Communications Center 911 Clackamas 911 - CCOM

post_text:
After meeting with Marion County officials, we have decided to postpone the start of this school year until Monday, September 14. There will be no comprehensive distance learning Thursday, September 10, or Friday, September 11. We will not have meal service either day and staff does not need to report.

Our hearts go out to everyone affected by the fires. Please take care of yourself and your families.

post_text: Due to emergency evacuations and potential fire danger, we will not have distance learning today (Tuesday, September 8). District offices will be closed and there will be no meal service. We apologize for the inconvenience. Please stay safe!
text: Due to emergency evacuations and potential fire danger, we will not have distance learning today (Tuesday, September 8). District offices will be closed and there will be no meal service. We apologize for the inconvenience. Please stay safe!

post_text:
Burkland Pool

Today (September 1), we were notified that a lifeguard at the Burkland pool tested positive for COVID-19. We understand that has raised safety concerns. We are working closely with the Marion County Health Department to respond to this news and protect the health of our community. This lifeguard was not in contact with any pool visitors. Because of contact tracing, we were able to identify the people who may have come in contact with the virus and those people have been notified by the county health department. Marion County Health officials have reached out to those who need to be tested and quarantined. Out of an abundance of caution, we’ve decided to close the pool for the rest of the week.

We have some updates for you as the Oregon Department of Education updated meal distribution requirements today. Now, anyone 1-18 can pick-up a meal FOR FREE!

This will look the same as it did in the spring. Anyone 1-18 can pick up a meal for free from 12:00-1:15 at Turner, Aumsville, or Cloverdale Elementary. Students do not need to be present to receive a meal. We hope to see you for lunch beginning on September 8.

post_text:
Español: https://bit.ly/2QBEWR4

Cascade Families,

This week, we welcomed the staff back into our school buildings. They have spent the week learning and developing our new online curriculum, creating lessons, and planning for a virtual classroom experience. I have been so inspired by the way our staff is leaning on one another and working hard to make sure distance learning works for every student. I can not wait to see their creativity in action when the school year begins.

There have been a number of questions surrounding students coming into the school buildings during distance learning. The Oregon Department of Education’s Ready Schools, Safe Learners guidance outlines the details of how and when schools can provide limited in-person instruction. The district is currently working on a plan to offer limited in-person instruction and we are hopeful that we will begin that instruction on October 5. Between now and then, we will evaluate every student. Based on the evaluation, some students may come in regularly and other students may come in less often. Limited in-person instruction will be optional and students who do not feel comfortable coming into school buildings will not be required to do so. We will share more information about how this will work as we get farther into September. Our goal at Cascade will be to bring in as many students as we can as often as we can while still following the guidelines.

Our meal service will begin at the start of the school year, on September 8. Cascade School District is offering meal pickup from 12:00-1:15 at Turner, Aumsville, and Cloverdale Elementary schools. Students on free or reduced lunch can pick up a free lunch with a grab-and-go breakfast included. This is limited to one meal per student per day. Students who are not on free or reduced lunch can still purchase a meal at any elementary school location if they would like to. Students do not need to be present to receive a meal. The state has updated the requirements to qualify for free or reduced lunch. Any household up to 300% above the poverty line qualifies for free or reduced lunch. We encourage you to complete the meal application form and return it to your students’ school office. If you are unsure if you qualify, please visit the Oregon Department of Education website.

We are continuing to get questions about technology resources. Due to high demand, we temporarily disabled our Access to Technology survey so that our technology department can process requests. We will open that survey back up as soon as possible. If you have already completed the survey, you will hear from your students’ school early next week. We will only be able to provide a maximum of two Chromebooks per household at this time. Unfortunately, the shipment of Chromebooks we ordered in early June is now on backorder until October. We plan to distribute these Chromebooks as soon as they arrive. We are working on a solution to this issue right now.

I encourage you to visit our Return to School 2020-21 webpage (https://bit.ly/32wwJ6w) for more information about the upcoming school year. If you have not done so already, please log in to the Parent Portal (https://bit.ly/TylerSIS) and register your student for school. Registering your student as soon as possible will assist our staff with planning for the year. If you are still unsure if you want to register here at Cascade School District, please contact your building administrator and talk with them about any concerns you have. I believe that the education we provide this fall will be the best option because our staff from Kindergarten to 12th grade is outstanding and will connect with your student in a meaningful way.

Thank you for your patience and flexibility. We want the entire transition to online learning to go as smoothly as possible, but we also know that there may be glitches along the way. Please keep an open line of communication and reach out to me or your students’ school if you run into an issue. We will work hard to find a solution and we are going to make this school year the best we possibly can.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2E7TchK

Cascade Families,

I want to share more information about Comprehensive Distance Learning (CDL) and what it will look like for our students.

CDL is an educational model with consistent teacher connections. Teachers will be teaching live lessons every day. At the elementary level, these lessons will include math, reading, writing, science, social and emotional learning, art, music, and physical education. You can check out a sample elementary attached to this post.

At the secondary level, students will have multiple classes every day with a live lesson in each one. Sample secondary schedules are attached.

Students will be expected to log in to lessons every day. On the rare occasion that students can not join a daily lesson, the content will be recorded. Please plan on discussing this with your students’ teachers and administrators.

Attendance will be taken every day during CDL. A student is marked present for the day if he/she attends a live lesson, communicates with the teacher or staff via phone or email, or a student turns in a completed assignment. At the secondary level, attendance will be taken every day in every class.

With CDL, there will be opportunities to bring small groups of students into the school buildings for extra help. The details of this limited in-person education are still being finalized by the state and we will make a plan once we receive more guidance.

Earlier this week, I shared some information about the differences between CDL and Cascade’s Online model. If you’ve registered for the 2020-21 school year, you will be receiving an email asking if you would like your student to start the year with CDL or our online model. We recommend enrolling in our CDL plan at the start of the school year to have access to all of our teachers and staff. When the time comes to transition to in-person learning, CDL students who do not feel comfortable returning to school can switch to our online school.

Paper packets will not be an option for primary learning. Teachers may use paper materials to supplement their lessons. Technology resources will be available for students in both CDL and Cascade’s Online model. Our technology staff is reaching out to families who have responded to our Access to Technology survey. We plan on providing Chromebooks and assistance with internet access to every family who needs help.

Please visit the Return to School 2020-21 Section (https://bit.ly/3g1rn7M) on our website for more information about CDL, Cascade’s Online Model, and our Operational Plans for the upcoming school year. Next week, your students’ principals will share more information about the start of the school year and provide opportunities for questions.

Thank you for your patience and flexibility.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3kHN4gE

Dear Cascade Families,

At the August 10 School Board meeting, we shared our Operational Blueprint for the 2020-21 school year. Our plan will start with all students in Comprehensive Distance Learning (CDL) and will move to in-person education should state and county metrics allow our schools to re-open. Our hope is that we can meet these metrics by the middle of October. We will also be providing an online learning option throughout the entire school year for those families who are considering keeping their children home.

The first step is registering your students for the 2020-21 school year. Please do so as soon as possible. If you have registered, you will receive an email next week asking if you would like to enroll your student in our CDL model or our online school. We know our teachers and staff are what makes our district work so well. We recommend enrolling in our CDL plan at the start of the school year to have access to all of our teachers and staff. When the time comes to transition to in-person learning, CDL students who do not feel comfortable returning to school can switch to our online school.

The attached graphic explains the differences between CDL and Cascade’s Online School.

To sum things up, CDL is an online educational program focused on teachers consistently connecting with students and families. This will be different from what we experienced this spring. CDL will include live instruction and access to teachers. There will be opportunities for small groups of students to come to school buildings for extra help. This option is likely the best choice for families who plan to send their students to schools when they open to in-person education.

Meanwhile, our Cascade Online option is a curriculum designed for online education where students can work at their own pace or on their own schedule. This option is likely the best choice for families who are sure they are going to educate your student online the entire school year.

When we meet the state and county health metrics and students return to our school buildings, all students in the CDL model will have the option to transition to Cascade Online if families are uncomfortable sending their student to in-person schooling. Students who start the school year in Cascade Online will only be able to transition to CDL or in-person schooling at the end of a trimester.

We will have technology resources available for students who enroll in CDL and our online model. If you have not done so, please make sure to take our Access to Technology survey (https://bit.ly/3gE32pZ).

Instruction for both CDL and our online school begins on September 8, 2020. The School Board approved the updated school-year calendar at their August 10 meeting. The updated school calendar can be found here. (https://bit.ly/newcal202021) Cascade School District and your child's school will provide more details as we get closer to the beginning of the school year.

We will continue to actively work on addressing concerns, assessing the health and safety status, and providing any necessary training for our teachers, staff, and administrators. We are compiling a list of “Frequently Asked Questions” and we will share it when it is finalized. Please regularly check the COVID-19 Hub on our website for updates and if you have any questions.

Thank you again for all you do to support your student(s) and our school district!

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3a6oMIj

Cascade Families,

Our students, families, and staff deserve as much certainty and stability as possible in an uncertain time. We also know that both Marion County and the state of Oregon are currently not meeting the lower rate of new coronavirus infections to safely return students to buildings under the updated state guidelines. This leads to an important update for the return to learning this fall. Our plan for the upcoming school year is, to begin with, Comprehensive Distance Learning (CDL).

Comprehensive Distance Learning

This version of CDL will look a lot different than what we experienced this previous spring. This is a completely virtual school experience with a curriculum designed for online learning. Cascade staff members and teachers will help facilitate this online program and will be available to students who need help. This online option will be more robust than what we experienced in the spring with a consistent connection to instructors and more training for our staff members. To help us finalize our plan for CDL, please take a moment to fill our Access to Technology Survey so we can ensure every student gets the resources they need to be successful.

We will share our official CDL plan on our website by August 15. Please make sure to check out the COVID-19 Hub on our website for information about the start of the school year and other resources.

We are also planning to push the start of the school year for students to Tuesday, September 8, 2020. The Cascade School District Board will need to approve this change on August 10. This extra week will give us time to train staff on our CDL plan and ensure they can provide the best possible education for our students.

Assuming that we can meet the state and county health metrics at some point, the first possible dates that we could return to an in-person learning model would be the week of October 19 - 23, 2020. This will be approximately at the halfway point of our trimester calendar. We will provide all families with information about transitioning to in-person schooling as we get closer to those dates.

Our students receiving special education services or English language development support will be taught by our specialists using virtual tools where possible. We are looking at multiple means of supporting our students with differing learning needs, and updated information will be available by the end of August.

Online Learning

We will be providing an online learning option throughout the entire school year for those families who are considering keeping their children home. There are many options out there, however, we believe that the program we will be offering will deliver the excellent education our district is known for. This curriculum is specifically designed for online learning with access to Cascade teachers and staff to help facilitate the program. Any students that choose Cascade’s online model will still be able to be a part of activities and athletics when they become available during the school year.

Registration

Returning students in all grade levels can register online for the new school year. Please register your students by August 21. We encourage all families to register online if possible.

Parents, simply login to the Parent Portal and complete your student’s registration. If you are unsure of how to register your student online, please take a moment to watch the following video.

We will have in-person registration available for new students or families without internet access. New students will need to bring their immunization records and proof of age. If you are new to the district and do not feel comfortable registering in person, please call your student’s school to make alternate arrangements.

In-person registration for our elementary schools is August 11 and 12. COVID guidelines will apply. Listed below are the available times.

Cloverdale Elementary: Appointment only, please call the school office (503-749-8050) to schedule an appointment
Turner Elementary: August 11 from 11 AM - 7 PM and August 12 from 7:30 AM - 3 PM
Aumsville Elementary: 7:30 AM - 3:30 PM on both days

In-person registration for junior high and high school students is the week of August 17th. Families must make an appointment to register in-person. COVID guidelines will apply. To register, please call the following number:

Junior High: 503-749-8030
High School: 503-749-8020

Please note that staff will not be in the office until August 10th.

Students at the Cascade Opportunity Center will also register the week of August 17th. Staff will be reaching out to students and families to schedule appointments.

Athletics Updates

On August 5, the Oregon School Activities Association (OSAA) announced an update to the athletics and activities calendar for the 2020-21 school year. The full release by OSAA can be found here.

The OSAA’s new calendar includes three distinct seasons: traditional Winter activities will take place in January and February, followed by Fall activities in March and April, with Spring activities occurring in May and June. Each season will feature a 7-week regular season, with adjusted contest limitations, followed by an OSAA Culminating Week. Specific plans for culminating week events will be developed in the coming months.

This also means that fall youth camps and sports will be postponed. Youth football plans are set and can be found here. Please check the Cascade Athletics website for any athletics updates.

Thank you for your understanding and grace as we navigate the challenges of returning to learning in the midst of an ongoing pandemic. We continue to plan and prepare for the day that we will be able to welcome students safely back to school buildings. Online or on-site, Cascade School District will continue to provide the best education and care we can for all of our students.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Español: https://bit.ly/3f979IL

Cascade Families,

Yesterday, Oregon Governor Kate Brown announced a new set of metrics (https://bit.ly/2ExtuDq) that will determine when schools can safely reopen their buildings to return to in-person learning. These metrics apply to both everyday schooling as well as hybrid education.

This is not the news we were hoping to share today. We recognize the important role schools play in the lives of our students, families, and our community. Our staff had been looking forward to solving the unique challenges we’re facing to work directly with students in our classrooms. We are hopeful that the opportunity will still happen this fall. The safety and wellbeing of our students and staff is our priority. We know we can provide high-quality education to every student through the learning models we can provide at this time.

What I can share with you today is the following:

1) As of today, July 29, 2020, it is likely that we will start all grades and all classes in a Comprehensive Distance Learning model. Almost every public and private school in the state will have to start school this way based on the Governor and Oregon Health Authority’s health metrics.

2) Cascade School District will review updated state and county health metrics early next week and will provide you with a final decision on August 7, 2020, about how schools will open. Between now and then, I would begin making arrangements for students to be learning from home for the first part of the school year.

3) Regardless of how we start the school year, the first day of classes will likely begin on Tuesday, September 8, 2020, the day after Labor Day. The Cascade School District Board will need to approve this change at their August meeting. This extra week will give all staff time to receive additional training.

4) While it seems likely that we will start this school year online, Cascade School District will monitor the state and county health metrics weekly and move to in-person instruction as soon as we can.

5) Assuming that we can meet the state and county health metrics at some point, the first possible dates that we could return to an in-person learning model would be the week of October 19 - 23, 2020. This will be approximately at the halfway point of our trimester calendar. We will provide all families with information about this possible transition as we get closer to those dates.

6) If you have a student that will be in Kindergarten through 3rd grade this year, the state and county health metrics are less strict for these students to attend classes in person. When Marion County meets these metrics, we will be able to bring K-3rd grade students in as soon as it is feasible. This may mean that we could get these students into in-person classes before October 19- 23, 2020. Please keep checking your email, our website, and our social media sites for updates on this.

7) Cascade School District will continue to provide a comprehensive online school model for the entire 2020-21 school year for any families that feel safer learning from home. For students that choose Cascade’s online model, they will be able to be a part of activities and athletics when they become available during the school year.

Please check back frequently over the next few weeks. Plans can be changed right away due to updates we receive from the state agencies. We will do our best to review state-level changes and get you updated changes as soon as we can.

Thank you for your patience as we get started with a very unusual year. I am asking every family to please give grace and flexibility to each other, the teachers and educators in every school building, and to all staff here at Cascade as we work together to make the best of this difficult situation.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent
text:
Español: https://bit.ly/3f979IL

Cascade Families,

Yesterday, Oregon Governor Kate Brown announced a new set of metrics (https://bit.ly/2ExtuDq) that will determine when schools can safely reopen their buildings to return to in-person learning. These metrics apply to both everyday schooling as well as hybrid education.

This is not the news we were hoping to share today. We recognize the important role schools play in the lives of our students, families, and our community. Our staff had been looking forward to solving the unique challenges we’re facing to work directly with students in our classrooms. We are hopeful that the opportunity will still happen this fall. The safety and wellbeing of our students and staff is our priority. We know we can provide high-quality education to every student through the learning models we can provide at this time.

What I can share with you today is the following:

1) As of today, July 29, 2020, it is likely that we will start all grades and all classes in a Comprehensive Distance Learning model. Almost every public and private school in the state will have to start school this way based on the Governor and Oregon Health Authority’s health metrics.

2) Cascade School District will review updated state and county health metrics early next week and will provide you with a final decision on August 7, 2020, about how schools will open. Between now and then, I would begin making arrangements for students to be learning from home for the first part of the school year.

3) Regardless of how we start the school year, the first day of classes will likely begin on Tuesday, September 8, 2020, the day after Labor Day. The Cascade School District Board will need to approve this change at their August meeting. This extra week will give all staff time to receive additional training.

4) While it seems likely that we will start this school year online, Cascade School District will monitor the state and county health metrics weekly and move to in-person instruction as soon as we can.

5) Assuming that we can meet the state and county health metrics at some point, the first possible dates that we could return to an in-person learning model would be the week of October 19 - 23, 2020. This will be approximately at the halfway point of our trimester calendar. We will provide all families with information about this possible transition as we get closer to those dates.

6) If you have a student that will be in Kindergarten through 3rd grade this year, the state and county health metrics are less strict for these students to attend classes in person. When Marion County meets these metrics, we will be able to bring K-3rd grade students in as soon as it is feasible. This may mean that we could get these students into in-person classes before October 19- 23, 2020. Please keep checking your email, our website, and our social media sites for updates on this.

7) Cascade School District will continue to provide a comprehensive online school model for the entire 2020-21 school year for any families that feel safer learning from home. For students that choose Cascade’s online model, they will be able to be a part of activities and athletics when they become available during the school year.

Please check back frequently over the next few weeks. Plans can be changed right away due to updates we receive from the state agencies. We will do our best to review state-level changes and get you updated changes as soon as we can.

Thank you for your patience as we get started with a very unusual year. I am asking every family to please give grace and flexibility to each other, the teachers and educators in every school building, and to all staff here at Cascade as we work together to make the best of this difficult situation.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

CASCADECOUGARS.COM
Cascade High School

post_text:
Español: https://bit.ly/39y9X0V

July 27, 2020

Dear Parents and Guardians,

Thank you for your quick reply to the Parent Survey! It was helpful to get a sense of the general trends in family preferences as we continue to plan and prepare. We completely understand that some parents are not yet able to decide or may change their thinking as things are evolving so quickly.

The district is developing a comprehensive plan to support students’ well-being and academic progress while protecting students and staff from the spread of COVID-19. While the detailed plan is not final, and there are still many unknowns, we want to share the overall framework to help families start planning for the year ahead.

We will have in-person instruction Monday-Friday for all K-8 students. Our high school students will attend school on an A/B schedule. Again, the details of these plans are not final yet, but our survey (https://bit.ly/305wIGx) showed overwhelming support for in-person instruction, and we feel this is the best way to provide quality education for all our students at this time. Our in-person instruction will follow the guidance set by the Oregon Department of Education and will look different than prior school years. We appreciate your grace and patience as we work to support every student and family.

For our families who are unsure or uncertain about sending students to school in-person, we will be rolling out our Cascade School District Online Program. This is a completely virtual school experience with a curriculum designed for online learning. Cascade staff members and teachers will help facilitate this online program and will be available to students who need help. This online option will be more robust than what we experienced in the spring with a consistent connection to instructors and more training for our staff members.

We hope that by having both an in-person and an online option, we will be able to meet the needs of all of our students and families.

Please also note that at any point, the Governor or the Oregon Department of Education can determine that in-person schooling is no longer safe. At that point, we will transition all of our students to our Cascade School District Online Program. We are working on putting a transition plan together in the event of a shutdown from state officials.

With all these potential changes, our staff will need additional training to prepare for the fall. It is likely that we will push the start of the school year back to September 8 in order to properly prepare our staff. We can not make this decision official until it is reviewed by our staff and approved by our school board. After the August 10 board meeting, we will immediately announce a change to the calendar if the school board agrees.

The Oregon Department of Education requires an Operational Blueprint to reopen schools. It will provide specifics about how we at Cascade will reopen while keeping our students and staff safe. Again this needs to go through our school board, but it will be available for public viewing on our website after the August 10 board meeting.

I know you have questions. We will do our best to answer every question, so keep an eye out for upcoming Q&A sessions and other forums after we unveil our Operational Blueprint.

Thank you for your patience and understanding. We look forward to sharing more with you as we finalize our plan for Fall 2020.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text: SIT Mobile services are still available to those who need any assistance
text: SIT Mobile services are still available to those who need any assistance

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3e9NQPV

Cascade Families,

Last week the Oregon Department of Education released this guidance (https://bit.ly/37C1TeT) outlining how to open our schools in the fall in the safest manner possible. Please keep in mind, this is just the first set of guidance. We are expecting updated guidance on June 30th as well as more clarity as the summer continues. We will revise our plans as necessary.

There is so much information in this initial guidance and we are currently analyzing and assessing what this means for the Cascade School District right now. One thing is certain, we will keep you updated as plans develop and provide opportunities for feedback as we progress. Please keep checking your email as we will be sending out a survey in the next couple of weeks.

A few important highlights of the guidance (though this is far from all of it!):

Face coverings are required for some of our staff who come into close contact with students and are recommended for all staff.

Face coverings are not recommended or required for students younger than 6th grade.

Face coverings are recommended for students in 6th - 12th grade, but not required.

Physical distancing of up to 6 ft or 35 square feet per student in space is required. (We will need to calculate what this means for our class sizes and the number of students we can have in a building at one time.)

We will need to stagger where students enter and exit the building and keep track of who’s coming in and out.

Playgrounds will be open to students during the school day (limited groups at a time) and sanitized between use.

We will need to keep student groups together (such as classes) to the extent possible.

We will need to work with our health department in the event of a case or an outbreak.

Our main goal is and will continue to be getting every student into the classroom. If you are uncomfortable with the plans we create, we will do everything in our power to meet you at your level and find a solution that works best for you and your student(s).

Just like we did in the spring, we will get through this together! Please know that, throughout our planning, we will always keep in mind that our schools must continue to be warm, caring communities, even with these new rules.

Thank you for your continued patience and grace as we work through this together with our students’ best interests in our hearts.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text: Thank you Mr. Schmotzer for your years at Cascade. You've touched the lives of so many. Enjoy your retirement!
shared_text:
Cascade Junior High School
June 11 at 5:23 PM ·

GOOD-BYES ARE NEVER FUN NOR EASY!

This year we say good-bye to a staff member who has been around for a very long time. John Schmotzer has been with the Cascade School District for 39 years and has decided to retire. He spent his first couple years at North Santiam Elementary then moved to Aumsville Elementary when it closed. When Aumsville moved its 5th graders to Turner Elementary, Mr. Schmotzer moved with them. He returned to Aumsville when the primary building was opened to continue teaching 5th grade. Finally, Mr. Schmotzer has spent the last 9 years teaching 6th grade at the junior high. He has spent 41 total years in education. He jokingly says that this coming fall will be the first time he has not started a school year, as a student or teacher, since first grade. That's a lot of school starts.

We wish him all the best in the new chapter in his life! We will miss you around here, John!!!

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/37f93Fw

Cascade Families,

Congratulations on reaching the end of the school year. I am so proud of each and every one of you for your flexibility and resilience during this crazy time. Our teachers and staff members have shown a tremendous amount of the creativity these last few months. I am especially proud of our students for adapting and adjusting to this situation and working hard to finish the school year.

Today, June 9, is our last day serving meals at our elementary school locations. Thank you to our lunch staff for serving our families these last few months. I am so grateful for your hard work and I know our community appreciated the time you put in.

The state has started a new program called the Pandemic-EBT (P-EBT). This gives extra grocery money to families with children on free or reduced meals. For each month that school is closed and you are eligible, you will get $5.70 per day for each of your children at a K-12 school. There are three ways your family can receive the benefit. One, if you already get SNAP, the extra money will be automatically loaded on your Oregon Trail EBT card. Two, if you do not have SNAP, but already qualify for free or reduced school meals, a new EBT card will be automatically mailed to you with instructions. Three, you can apply for free or reduced meals on the Oregon Department of Education Website. You will automatically be given Pandemic EBT benefits starting the month you’re approved for either free school meals or SNAP. Immigration status does not matter for Pandemic EBT. Many families will automatically get Pandemic EBT. You can learn more about eligibility or how to receive the benefit at oregonhunger.org/covid-19 or by calling 2-1-1.

With this school year coming to a close, we are planning for the transition into 2020-2021. We are preparing for several possible scenarios for returning to school, including heading back to schools and classrooms with moderate social distancing requirements; a hybrid of classroom and remote learning instruction; or fully remote learning. We expect initial guidance from the Oregon Department of Education within the next week. Keep an eye out as we will connect with families to solicit feedback about distance learning and what we may be able to do to improve education in the fall in order to come up with a plan that works best for our community. No matter what the next school year looks like, we will deliver excellent education because that is what we do in this district.

Again, thank you for sticking with us. Have a wonderful and relaxing summer. Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Cascade Community, SIT Mobile services are continuing through the end of June.

What do they do?

They deliver essential items to your home and leave them on the doorstep. Once the items are left on the doorstep they notify you.

They also can shop for families and seniors.

Need your prescriptions picked up? They are partnering with Aumsville Police Department, Stayton Police Station, and Turner Police Department to pick up prescriptions and deliver.

Who do they serve? ANYONE who contacts for help in the Santiam Region including from Idanha to Turner.

What items are available for delivery? Laundry Detergent, Dish Soap, Cleaning Spray, Toilet Paper, Paper Towels, hygiene items, Hand Sanitizer, Dental Supplies, Bottled Water, Food Items, Depends, Adult Wash Clothes, Ensure, Diapers, Wipes, Diaper Rash Cream, baby formula, dog and cat food, Chap Stick, Masks, and more.

Families and individuals can access the services more than once.

Community members can text or call the 503-409-3652 phone line or email sitmobile@santiamhospital.org

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3cweoJA

Cascade Families,

I want to communicate some final updates as we wrap up this school year.

We will celebrate the Class of 2020 on June 5 and 6. The celebration includes a parade through Aumsville and Turner beginning at 4 pm on Saturday. The parade will begin and end at Cascade High School. Turn by turn directions can be found here (https://bit.ly/2MnjpK3). We hope to see you along the parade route but remember to please adhere to social distancing guidelines.

We will begin summer school next week at the secondary level. Staff will be reaching out to students and families to make a plan for summer school education. We are still determining if and when we will be able to safely have summer school for our elementary students. We will relay that information to you as soon as possible. Our outdoor athletic facilities will be closed until at least June 15. Coaches will be reaching out to athletes to make a plan for summer training.

Please return your Chromebooks to our schools on June 5, June 8, and June 9. Elementary Chromebooks can be returned to the schools from 11-1 on June 5 and 8 or by appointment on June 9. Secondary staff will be reaching out to families regarding the times for Chromebook returns. We need all Chromebooks to be returned even if your student is participating in summer school. Chromebooks will be cleaned and re-checked out to students who need the technology to access summer school.

We will not be serving meals tomorrow, June 3, at our elementary school locations. Students received additional meals for tomorrow during today’s lunch pick-up. Our meal distribution will resume on Thursday, June 4. We apologize for the inconvenience. Remember, the final day for meal distribution is June 9.

As we wind down this school year, we are already preparing for the transition into 2020-2021. We are preparing for several possible scenarios for returning to school, including heading back to schools and classrooms with moderate social distancing requirements; a hybrid of classroom and remote learning instruction; or fully remote learning. Keep an eye out as we will connect with families to solicit feedback about distance learning and what we may be able to do to improve education in the fall in order to come up with a plan that works best for our community. No matter what the next school year looks like, we will deliver excellent education because that is what we do in this district.

Thank you for sticking with us as we navigated this unprecedented time. Let’s finish the year strong and celebrate our resilient students and families.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

The parade will begin and end at Cascade High School. Turn by turn directions can be found here (https://bit.ly/2MnjpK3). We hope to see you along the parade route but remember to please adhere to social distancing guidelines.

We will begin summer school next week at the secondary level. Staff will be reaching out to students and families to make a plan for summer school education. We are still determining if and when we will be able to safely have summer school for our elementary students. We will relay that information to you as soon as possible. Our outdoor athletic facilities will be closed until at least June 15. Coaches will be reaching out to athletes to make a plan for summer training.

Please return your Chromebooks to our schools on June 5, June 8, and June 9. Elementary Chromebooks can be returned to the schools from 11-1 on June 5 and 8 or by appointment on June 9. Secondary staff will be reaching out to families regarding the times for Chromebook returns. We need all Chromebooks to be returned even if your student is participating in summer school. Chromebooks will be cleaned and re-checked out to students who need the technology to access summer school.

We will not be serving meals tomorrow, June 3, at our elementary school locations. Students received additional meals for tomorrow during today’s lunch pick-up. Our meal distribution will resume on Thursday, June 4. We apologize for the inconvenience. Remember, the final day for meal distribution is June 9.

As we wind down this school year, we are already preparing for the transition into 2020-2021. We are preparing for several possible scenarios for returning to school, including heading back to schools and classrooms with moderate social distancing requirements; a hybrid of classroom and remote learning instruction; or fully remote learning. Keep an eye out as we will connect with families to solicit feedback about distance learning and what we may be able to do to improve education in the fall in order to come up with a plan that works best for our community. No matter what the next school year looks like, we will deliver excellent education because that is what we do in this district.

Thank you for sticking with us as we navigated this unprecedented time. Let’s finish the year strong and celebrate our resilient students and families.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2ZHEMNQ

Cascade Families,

I hope you enjoyed your long weekend and used the time to refresh as we head into the final weeks of the school year. As we wind down this school year, we have received many questions about the 2020-21 school year. We need to be prepared for several possible scenarios for returning to school, based on direction and guidance from the Governor’s Office and the Oregon Department of Education. Possible scenarios include heading back to schools and classrooms with moderate social distancing requirements; a hybrid of classroom and remote learning instruction; or fully remote learning. While we do not know what the year will look like, I can guarantee we will have the best plan in place for every scenario. I can also guarantee you that no matter what next school year looks like, we will deliver excellent education because that is what we do in this district.

We are also working on a plan for summer programs and activities. In the past, our facilities have been used for summer school, summer camps, and summer workouts for athletics. We are working with staff to determine a way to still have some of these summer programs while keeping everyone safe and adhering to Oregon Health Authority guidelines. We will have that information for you as soon as possible.

With the end of the school year approaching, there are a few dates to keep in mind. Our final packet pickup will be June 1. Those packets will need to be returned Friday, June 5. This will allow materials to sit the required 48 hours over the weekend and give our staff time to grade materials before the final day of school on June 9. On Monday, June 8, we will have fun summer activities and supplemental materials available at packet pickup. These will be optional activities for your students.

We will collect Chromebooks on June 5, June 8, and June 9. Elementary Chromebooks can be returned to the schools from 11-1 on June 5 and 8 or by appointment on June 9. Secondary staff will be reaching out to families regarding the times for Chromebook returns.

We will be celebrating our senior class on Friday and Saturday, June 5 and 6. Seniors will get a chance to walk across the stage with select family members and friends present. Late Saturday afternoon there will be a graduate parade through Aumsville and Turner where our whole community can celebrate the senior class. Our junior high staff will celebrate the eighth-grade class on June 8. Our elementary schools have planned celebrations for their fifth-grade and kindergarten classes. Please contact your students’ schools or teachers for more information.

Again, thank you for your patience as we navigate this ever-changing situation. Let’s finish the year strong.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

May 22 at 6:20 AM ·

From Linda’s family,

We would like to tell all of her friends and family that we think she would want to say this....
I have left my place here on this earth but, have fond, caring loving memories from each and everyone of you. You all have a special place in my heart and was so blessed I got to be a part of your lives. post_text: We are AVID district-wide. Congratulations to our first graduating class of AVID seniors. We are so proud of you and your accomplishments. Thank you for making an incredible impact on the Cascade Community
shared_text:
YOUTUBE.COM
AVID Senior Video

Cascade High School
May 22 at 5:50 PM ·

Four years ago, the Cascade School District introduced the AVID program to our high school. AVID, Advancement Via Individual Determination, has two goals. One is to introduce and train staff in the most effective teaching strategies available; and the other is the AVID elective, where students apply to be part of a program that seeks to prepare students for college and career readiness. Integral to the class is writing, inquiry, collaboration, organization, and reading skills, known as WICOR. Central to Cascade's program is community service and experiential education. Cascade just graduated its first AVID class. Collectively the class completed over 4,500 hours of community service and thus far, earned $486,000 in scholarships. Cascade is proud of the AVID class of 2020 and the community they have served.

post_text:
Información en Español: https://bit.ly/2zSvcwV

Cascade Families,

We are in the final stretch of the school year with just three weeks left until summer. While we are still awaiting further guidance from the Oregon Department of Education, the district is already thinking about what the start of the next school year will look like. We don’t yet know if the start of the school year will be face-to-face, online, or a combination of both, but we will have the best plan in place for every scenario. I can also guarantee you that no matter what next school year looks like, we will deliver excellent education because that is what we do in this district. We will continue to do what is best for students and families and we will share information about the return to school as it becomes available.

As we head into these final weeks, there are some dates I’d like you to keep in mind. Next Monday, May 25, is Memorial Day, so we will have packet-handout and distance learning materials available on Tuesday, May 26. Packet pickup times and locations will remain the same. Our final packet pickup will be June 1. Those packets will need to be returned Friday, June 5. This will allow materials to sit the required 48 hours over the weekend and give our staff time to grade materials before the final day of school on June 9. On Monday, June 8, we will have fun summer activities and supplemental materials available at packet pickup. These will be optional activities for your students.

We will collect Chromebooks on June 5, June 8, and June 9. Elementary Chromebooks can be returned to the schools from 11-1 on June 5 and 8 or by appointment on June 9. Secondary staff will be reaching out to families regarding the times for Chromebook returns.

We will continue serving meals through June 9. The state has also started a new program called the Pandemic-EBT (P-EBT). This gives extra grocery money to families with children on free or reduced meals. For each month that school is closed and you are eligible, you will get $5.70 per day for each of your children at a K-12 school. There are three ways your family can receive the benefit. One, if you already get SNAP, the extra money will be automatically loaded on your Oregon Trail EBT card. Two, If you do not have SNAP, but already qualify for free or reduced school meals, a new EBT card will be automatically mailed to you with instructions. Three, you can apply for free or reduced meals on the Oregon Department of Education Website. You will automatically be given Pandemic EBT benefits starting the month you’re approved for either free school meals or SNAP. Immigration status does not matter for Pandemic EBT. Many families will automatically get Pandemic EBT. You can learn more about eligibility or how to receive the benefit at oregonhunger.org/covid-19 or by calling 2-1-1.

We will be celebrating our senior class on Friday and Saturday, June 5 and 6. Seniors will sign up for a time-slot to walk across the stage on June 5 or 6. This will be a chance for them to take pictures and celebrate with family and friends. Saturday afternoon there will be a graduate parade through Aumsville and Turner where our whole community can celebrate the senior class. I would like to thank Matt Thatcher and his staff for finding a creative way to honor the class of 2020.

Again, I have been so impressed with our parents, students, and staff for the resiliency and creativity they have shown during this time. Thank you for your patience. Let’s finish the year strong.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en Español: https://bit.ly/2WpT0kj

Cascade Families,

I want to start by acknowledging the resiliency of our students. It has been almost two months since things have drastically shifted. For students, that was an immediate change in their routine, their relationships, and their education. I have heard stories from parents and seen photos of students of all ages adapting to this new environment. I am so proud of every student for working hard to adjust to the unknown and to the parents, thank you for working hard for your students to help this transition go as smooth as possible.

I’d also like to recognize our staff. I’ve been so impressed with the creativity they’ve shown to deliver education and help families through this time. From Star Wars themed packet handouts to parades through town to simply calling students to check-in, their hard work has not gone unnoticed and I am truly grateful for our incredible staff.

This week, our high school staff will begin forecasting for next year. Students should receive a Google form from a staff member regarding signing up for next year’s classes. Please have your student contact his/her counselor if you do not receive a form by next week. Junior high students will begin forecasting in the next few weeks, so stay tuned for information from the junior high staff.

We are beginning to register incoming kindergarten students for the next school year. If you have a student who will be five on or before September 1, 2020, your child is eligible to start kindergarten in the fall. A staff member from your child’s school will be reaching out with specific kindergarten registration information. If you do not hear from your child’s school, please contact Shelly Baughman at Cloverdale Elementary, Molly Hunsaker at Turner Elementary or Jill Johnson at Aumsville Elementary.

We are waiting for guidance from the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) regarding summer school and summer camps. We expect to have these regulations in the next few days and will relay this information to you as soon as we can. We have also started planning for a return to our classrooms in the fall and we have begun developing alternative plans in case the start of school looks different. We will make decisions for our district based on what ODE mandates and what we feel works best to meet the needs of our students and staff. We will share this information with you as soon as we can.

I’d like to reiterate that we are here to help. ODE and our district have acknowledged that students must have their basic needs met first in order to be able to access their potential to learn. These needs include food, housing, safety, a sense of belonging, and relationships. We have resources to help you and your family, so please do not hesitate to reach out to our staff or visit our website (https://bit.ly/CSDHealthWellness).

Again, thank you, families, for your patience and support. We are in this together, so please reach out if you need anything. Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text:
Census results affect your community every day. This will impact our schools for the next ten years.

If you haven't already, please respond to the census.
My2020census.gov
shared_text:
City of Turner, Oregon
May 8 at 5:07 PM ·

More Census Information for those who use a PO BOX!

Everyone who lives in a place where there is no mail delivery and they must go to the post office to collect their mail should not go online and fill out the census until they receive the census packet. They will start delivering to those homes Monday morning. We call this Update Leave (UL). We had started UL before the state shut down over COVID-19 and we've just been given permission to start it up again.

In keeping with COVID-19 social distancing best practices, Census employees will be provided face masks, gloves and hand sanitizer for use while dropping off packets in Update Leave areas. Employees have also been instructed to not knock or ring the doorbell, but instead will simply leave the packet on the doorstep of the residence. Each packet contains:
• A paper Census questionnaire with Census ID
• Census phone number to take the Census with a live person over the phone
• My2020census.gov web address to respond to the Census online

We had started UL before the state shut down over COVID-19 and we've just been given permission to start it up again.

In keeping with COVID-19 social distancing best practices, Census employees will be provided face masks, gloves and hand sanitizer for use while dropping off packets in Update Leave areas. Employees have also been instructed to not knock or ring the doorbell, but instead will simply leave the packet on the doorstep of the residence. Each packet contains:
• A paper Census questionnaire with Census ID
• Census phone number to take the Census with a live person over the phone
• My2020census.gov web address to respond to the Census online

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3fqpuSX

Cascade Families,

I’d like to start by thanking our teachers and nurses. May 4-8 is Teacher and Nurse Appreciation Week. Whether serving in person or remotely, I know these staff members care deeply about every student. Thank you, staff, for everything you do for your students and families.

As of now, Oregon Governor Kate Brown has mandated that Oregon schools remain closed until June 30. We are waiting for guidance from the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) regarding summer school and re-opening in the fall. We have started planning for a return to our classrooms and we’ve also begun developing alternative plans in case the start of school looks different. We will make decisions for our district based on what ODE mandates and what we feel works best to meet the needs of our students and staff. We will share this information with you as soon as we can.

ODE and our district have acknowledged that students must have their basic needs met first in order to be able to access their potential to learn. These needs include food, housing, safety, a sense of belonging, and relationships. We have resources to help you and your family, so please do not hesitate to reach out to our staff or visit our website (https://bit.ly/CSDHealthWellness).

We had another record-breaking day of meal distribution on Monday. We served 2,046 meals at our elementary locations. Thank you, everyone, for making this possible. We are serving meals Monday-Friday from 12-1 at Aumsville Elementary and 12-12:45 at Turner and Cloverdale Elementaries. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

Again, thank you, families, for your patience and support. We are in this together, so please reach out if you need anything. Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text:
Cascade Families,

Thank you for your continued engagement with your student’s learning in this challenging environment. We are still adjusting our distance learning plan to fit what works best for our students. Please do not hesitate to reach out to our staff with feedback and let teachers know if your student needs resources for learning.

We are here to support you whether its food, learning support, or mental health resources. We have had gracious community members donate items for food baskets and our staff is willing and able to help. If there is anything we can do to help you and your family during this time, please do not hesitate to reach out to our staff or visit our website (https://bit.ly/CSDHealthWellness).

We have made an adjustment to the school-year calendar. You may remember that this Thursday and Friday, April 30 and May 1, were scheduled to be non-school days for students. Our plan was to have professional development for teachers and hold the annual AVID showcase. After meeting with our associations, we have decided that distance learning will continue on Thursday and Friday. These will be school days for students and workdays for our employees. This means we will end the school year two days earlier. The final day for students is June 9 and the final day for teachers is June 10. Please adjust your family calendars to reflect this change. The updated calendar can be found here (https://bit.ly/3aKiGvW).

We had another record-high day of meal distribution on Monday. We served 2,034 meals curbside. Thank you again to our staff for making this possible and feeding our community. Families, we will continue this service through the end of the school year, so please continue to utilize it. Meals are available Monday-Friday at Aumsville Elementary from 12-1 and Cloverdale and Turner Elementary from 12-12:45. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

Again thank you for your flexibility and patience.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3att5MD

Cascade Families,

Yesterday, I had the chance to stop by each elementary school packet pick-up location. I am so impressed with the way our staff has stepped up to make this part of distance learning a positive experience for our students and families. Each school had a fun atmosphere with music, dancing, and camaraderie. Remember, packet pick-up is every Monday from 11-1:30 at each elementary school. You can drop off the previous week’s packets at this time as well. If you have not received this week’s materials yet, they are available on the website (https://bit.ly/CSDDistanceLearning) or you can contact your student’s teachers and they will work something out for you.

We served a record 1,946 meals yesterday and every day our meal service is growing. I am so grateful for our staff that has gone above and beyond to serve our community. Families, I hope you will continue utilizing this service. We are serving meals Monday-Friday from 12-1 at Aumsville Elementary and 12-12:45 at Turner and Cloverdale Elementaries. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

I want to remind you that our district facilities are closed to the public at this time. This includes playgrounds, the football stadium, the track and other fields around our schools. Please refrain from using these facilities until we are given guidance that it is safe to do so.

To our seniors and families, you should have already heard from Mr. Thatcher regarding the official postponement of graduation. The good news is the high school staff are working hard to ensure that there will eventually be a great celebration. Whether this celebration is in July, August or even later, we will find a way to celebrate the Class of 2020.

A reminder that this will be my only email this week barring any unforeseen circumstances. In the meantime, feel free to reach out to the district or any school offices with questions. We have staff available to answer phones Monday-Friday from 9-3. To adhere to social distancing guidelines, we are limiting staffing in school offices. Please have patience with our staff and leave a message if you do not get through directly to a staff member. Someone will return your call in a timely fashion. You can also email your questions or concerns to communications@cascade.k12.or.us.

Finally, I am deeply grateful for the grace, empathy, and compassion that has been on display in our district as we work together to support each other through this public health crisis.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,
Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2KgDW1Q

Cascade Families,

We are wrapping up our first week of Distance Learning. Elementary materials can be dropped off on Monday from 11-1:30 at either Cloverdale, Turner or Aumsville Elementary. New packets will be available for pick-up at that time. Junior High packets can be returned at any elementary location from 11-1:30 and new materials will be available. If you have junior high students that need materials in packet form, please contact the school as those packets are put together for individual students depending on their schedule. High school teachers and staff will be reaching out with distance learning materials.

This week, the Oregon Department of Education put out guidance regarding special education. Our district is prioritizing health and wellness and our goal is to provide an equitable education for all students. For more information on distance learning as it pertains to special education, please visit our website (https://bit.ly/COVIDSped).

I want to remind you that our district facilities are closed to the public at this time. This includes playgrounds, the football stadium, the track and other fields around our schools. Please refrain from using these facilities until we are given guidance that it is safe to do so.

We served 6,694 meals this week including a record-high 1,776 meals on Monday. We are serving about 95% of what we would serve during a normal school day. Thank you for utilizing this service. Also, a huge thank you to our staff for preparing and distributing these meals to our families. I am grateful for their hard work and I know our community appreciates it as well. Meals are available for pickup from 12-1 at Aumsville Elementary and 12-12:45 at Turner and Cloverdale Elementaries. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

Beginning next week, I will be reducing my emails to once per week barring any unforeseen circumstances. In the meantime, feel free to reach out to the district or any school offices with questions. We have staff available to answer phones Monday-Friday from 9-3. To adhere to social distancing guidelines, we are limiting staffing in school offices. Please have patience with our staff and leave a message if you do not get through directly to a staff member. Someone will return your call in a timely fashion. You can also email your questions or concerns to communications@cascade.k12.or.us.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2wFbVhb

Cascade Families,

This week we started our Distance Learning for All plan. If you have not received materials for this first week, please reach out to your student’s teacher(s) or school. As we continue with distance learning, I am asking students and families to please have patience as you work to connect and engage with your students’ teachers. Our staff is coming up with new creative ways to educate and it’s a learning process for everyone. Please know we are in this together.

My heart goes out to the senior class. I know this is not how you expected to spend your final year of high school. By now, you should have heard from Mr. Thatcher and Ms. Williams about graduation requirements. They are doing everything in their power to get seniors to the finish line. Please reach out if you have any questions or concerns about graduation requirements.

In honor of the class of 2020, stadium lights across America are being turned on at 8:20 pm, that’s 20:20 military time. Our stadium lights will be on for 20 minutes every Wednesday night until June 3rd. Hopefully, this beacon of light will help our community reflect on the amazing accomplishments of the senior class.

Our meal service has grown week by week. Yesterday, April 13, we served a record 1,776 meals. This is 95% of what we do on a normal school day across our district. Thank you for utilizing this service. Also, a huge thank you to our staff for preparing and distributing these meals to our families. I am grateful for their hard work and I know our community appreciates it as well. Meals are available for pickup from 12-1 at Aumsville Elementary and 12-12:45 at Turner and Cloverdale Elementaries. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

As we continue to provide meals and learning materials, we are in need of face masks for our staff to help ensure the safety of our staff, students and families. If you have face masks or can make face masks that you would be willing to donate, we would greatly appreciate it. Masks can be dropped off at the elementary schools during meal pickup times. Drop off is also available from 9-3 at the district office on the secondary campus. Many of you have already donated masks and we are so grateful for your willingness to help out.

As we move forward, we will continue to update our website (https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm) with information and resources. I encourage you to check it out. Stay safe and healthy and please reach out with any questions or concerns.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

Today, we start our Distance Learning Plan. Resources are available on our website: https://bit.ly/CSDDistanceLearning

You can pick up elementary materials on Mondays from 11-1:30 at Turner, Aumsville or Cloverdale Elementary. Junior High materials will be available at each elementary school. Packets can then be returned to teachers via email or there will be a packet drop-off box each Monday as well.

Junior High and High School teachers will also be reaching out to students with materials for their classes.

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/34plWLV

Cascade Families,

As you know we are moving forward with Distance Learning through the remainder of the school year. We will have new materials available each Monday. Your student’s teacher(s) will be reaching out with more information on distance learning. You can pick up elementary materials on Mondays from 11-1:30 at Turner, Aumsville or Cloverdale Elementary. Junior High materials will be available at each elementary school. High School teachers will be in touch with students to distribute materials. Packets can then be returned to teachers via email or there will be a packet drop-off box each Monday as well. As we move forward with distance learning, we will be regularly evaluating our education plans and will adjust as necessary. We appreciate your partnership and support in promoting your student’s well-being and continued learning.

When it comes to technology, our administrative staff is in the process of identifying the needs of our students. Due to our limited resources, we will be prioritizing the need for a computer in this order:

Seniors
High School Students Receiving Special Services
Kindergarten – 8th Grade Students Receiving Special Services
9th – 11th Grade Students
Kindergarten – 8th Grade Students

If a computer is checked out, families will need to have access to an internet connection. Unfortunately, the district is unable to provide connectivity. If your family already has a device, the district is asking you to help others by allowing families that do not have a device to have this accessibility. Regrettably, the district is only able to provide one device per family based on the criteria above. As per the Department of Education, students can also do paper packets and both ways of learning are acceptable. If you have additional questions, please contact your building principal.

We served 5,064 meals just this week. Our meal distribution is growing every week. I can not thank the staff enough for helping with meals and keeping our students fed. Remember, we are offering meals at all three elementary schools. You can pick up breakfast and lunch Monday-Friday from 12-1 at Aumsville Elementary and from 12-12:45 at Turner and Cloverdale Elementaries. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

While we continue to provide meals and learning materials, the CDC has put out new guidance regarding face masks and we are asking for some help from the community. We are in need of face masks for our staff to help ensure the safety of our staff, students and families. If you have face masks or can make face masks that you would be willing to donate, we would greatly appreciate it. Masks can be dropped off at the elementary schools during meal pickup times. Drop off is also available from 9-3 at the district office on the secondary campus. Many of you have already donated masks and we are so grateful for your willingness to help out.

Our district and schools will continue to communicate and engage with you as we move forward. We will get through this together, as a community. Thank you for your continued grace and support.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District
