post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2Vd99I9

Cascade Families,

I’m writing to share some important news. Today, Governor Kate Brown made the decision to close schools for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. The extended closure is an effort to slow the spread of COVID-19 and keep our community safe and healthy. During this closure extension, all school facilities will remain closed, however, student learning will continue, albeit in the new remote learning world.

I hoped that we would be able to welcome students back to school this year. Our staff members love seeing and serving your children at school! Instead, we will be focusing all of our effort on making remote learning the best it can be whether through packet or online format.

We understand that the continued closure of schools presents many challenges for students and families. It also raises many questions. We will continue to share further guidance as decisions are made and as information becomes available.

We will continue serving meals throughout the rest of the school year. Students can pick up a meal Monday-Friday at Cloverdale, Turner, and Aumsville Elementary. Due to a high volume, we are extending Aumsville’s meal pick-up time to 12-1. Cloverdale and Turner are also extending their meal pick-up time to 12-12:45. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

To our seniors, Gov. Brown also announced a plan surrounding graduation requirements. We are still digging into her recommendations but wanted to let you know that this will not impact seniors’ ability to graduate on time. Mr. Thatcher will be reaching out to you with more specifics on the plan for seniors for the rest of the school year. We expect to receive guidance from the Oregon Department of Education regarding credits for freshmen through juniors within the next week. We will relay that information to you as soon as we can.

We know that we are dealing with a never-seen-before health crisis that challenges us all--as parents, educators, and caregivers--to lead in the face of uncertainty and deliver education in new ways. I believe that if families, community partners, and schools work together, we will emerge as a stronger public school system. We will continue to be stronger together.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3aSQ9Fy

Cascade Families,

First of all, I want to thank you for your patience and support over these last few weeks. We are continuing to roll with the punches and trying to make the best possible decisions for the information we have at the time.

On April 6, we shared our supplemental education materials. These resources are available on the district website (https://bit.ly/CSDSupplemental). Packets were also available during Monday’s meal pickup. If you still need to pick up a packet, please call your student’s school to make arrangements.

Beginning April 13, we will be shifting gears to our Distance Learning for All plan. Our staff is working to deliver leveled curriculum, track and monitor student progress, assess student work, support student mental health and continue a personal relationship with every student. All of these education materials will be provided in online and packet format. Those materials will be emailed to families, available on the website and accessible during meal pickup. We will have more specific dates and times of packet distribution in the next few days.

We will continue serving meals at Cloverdale, Turner, and Aumsville Elementary. Due to a high volume, we are extending Aumsville’s meal pick-up time to 12-1. Cloverdale and Turner are also extending their meal pick-up time to 12-12:45. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals.

If you need additional assistance, the Cascade Service Integration Team (SIT) has created a Mobile SIT. They can assist anyone with their basic needs or who has compromised immunity. The team can deliver food, household items, and pick up prescriptions all free of charge. You can contact them for services via email (sitmobile@santiamhospital.org) or by phone at 503-409-3652.

While we continue to provide meals and learning materials, the CDC has put out new guidance regarding face masks and we are asking for some help from the community. We are in need of face masks for our staff to help ensure the safety of our staff, students and families. If you have face masks or can make face masks that you would be willing to donate, we would greatly appreciate it. Masks can be dropped off at the elementary schools during meal pickup times. Drop off will also be available from 9-3 at the district office on the secondary campus.

Finally, I want to thank our teachers and staff members for the hard work they have put in to come up with lesson plans, distribute meals and check-in with families. This is not easy and I am proud of the creativity they have shown as we adjust to this new way of teaching and learning.

Stay safe and stay healthy.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/3aIwnMK

Cascade Families,

We are excited to begin offering supplemental education tools on Monday, April 6. Supplemental education is resources to help your students retain skills they have already learned and to prevent regression. Supplemental materials will be available on our website (https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm). Elementary supplemental materials can also be picked up during that school’s meal pick-up. Junior High supplemental materials will be available at all of our meal pick-up locations. The high school has opted to focus directly on Distance Learning which will start April 13. Teachers may also be contacting you with supplemental resources.

After our supplemental education rolls out, we will quickly pivot to our Distance Learning for All plan beginning April 13. The Oregon Department of Education rolled out Distance Learning for All guidance this past Monday. Districts will now be required to deliver leveled curriculum, track and monitor student progress, assess student work, support student mental health and continue a personal relationship with every student. While this task provides a new challenge, our staff is already working on creative ways to provide this education to your student(s) and I have no doubt they will rise to the occasion. Some of our staff members have already reached out to students and families, and you should expect to hear from the rest of your student’s teachers within the next week. All of the educational materials will be available online and in packet form. More information will follow regarding the distribution of these materials.

In my opinion, one of the most significant disruptions is for our seniors. I know kids look forward to all of the experiences, competitions, and celebrations of senior year. It is hard for all of us to think about the impact COVID-19 is having on our students and families and the loss of the defining moments of senior year.

The Oregon Department of Education has stated that hopefully by April 10 they will provide updated graduation requirements that take into account input from a number of organizations to ensure that stakeholders, including higher education and the business community, recognize the value of high school diplomas earned during this time of unparalleled challenge.

We are continuing to serve meals at Cloverdale, Turner and Aumsville Elementaries, Monday-Friday from 12-12:30. Anyone 1-18 can receive lunch and a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Students do not need to be present to receive their meals. Over the last three weeks, the district has served 8,955 meals. Many thanks to all of our food service employees and those helping with meals during this tough time. Today we witnessed how much our community cares with signs and cards in the meal line. We appreciate all of your support.

Thank you for your patience and understanding as we move into this new way of teaching and learning.

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2JrBnt5

Cascade Families,

Last night, the Oregon Department of Education issued new guidance for schools that include shifting from supplemental education to distance learning for all. Oregon Schools are now required to provide more substantive, graded, potentially credit-bearing distance education for all students. We expect more details from the state on credit delivery over the next few days.

This shift by the state from ‘supplemental education’ to ‘graded’ is what our students deserve. It gives us a pathway that we did not previously have to provide credit for the work they do now, and through the current school year. This plan will give our youngest learners the skills and encouragement they need to advance and supports all learners with the teaching and learning they need to be successful. We are still waiting on the Department of Education’s guidelines around graduating seniors and we will share that guidance with you as soon as it is available.

Now, with new state direction, our teachers have the ability to do what they do best—connect with every student; be allowed to report on progress and provide official grades.

Oregon’s Distance Learning for All effort, while it will present challenges, allows us flexibility from the state to continue teaching and learning during this closure. It also draws on our core value to know every student by name, strength, and needs – no matter the challenge at hand.

As of now, our administration team and the teaching staff at each school will be working to figure out a “distance learning for all” plan that works for our district, our students and the resources we have available. Our “distance learning for all” plan will include online resources and packet material that will advance the grade-level curriculum and be required for a grade. It will also include check-ins from our staff. We will follow up with more guidance for you in the next few days.

As for the supplemental material, we still plan on having those resources available to you and your student on April 6. Those are optional activities for your student(s) to do in the meantime. Our “distance learning for all” materials will be available on April 13.

We will be here to support you, and your student(s), as we embark on this journey, together. Thank you for your strength, your compassion, and your ongoing efforts on behalf of our students.

Darin Drill, Superintendent Cascade School District

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm

It has been two weeks since Governor Brown’s order to cancel large gatherings to limit the spread of the COVID-19 virus. Since that time, we have experienced a school cancelation through March 31, and last week the cancelation was extended through April 28.

Our staff will be returning to work beginning on March 30. Most of our staff will be working remotely and the few employees who do come in the buildings will follow strict social distancing guidelines. Our staff will be putting together supplemental learning materials for students. These materials will be available to families beginning April 6. The goal is to provide students and families with some easy-to-implement activities to prevent regression and learning loss during an extended break. If you haven’t already, please take the time to fill our Home Technology Survey. This survey will help the district determine how best to provide educational support resources to our families.

In the coming days, we expect to receive information from the Oregon Department of Education about graduation requirements for seniors and we will relay this information to our seniors and families as soon as we can.

We will continue serving breakfast and lunch. Over the last two weeks, we’ve served 1,097 meals at Turner Elementary and 2,259 meals at Aumsville Elementary. Beginning March 30, we will be adding Cloverdale Elementary as a meal pickup location. Anyone ages 1-18 can pick up breakfast and lunch at any elementary school location from 12-12:30. Look for the orange tents outside of those schools, and there, you will find our staff handing out meals. Students no longer need to be present to receive a meal.

Finally, I want to encourage you to check our website where we’ve created a COVID-19 section (https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm). Here you will find resources for you and your student as well as regular updates from the district.

Thank you for your patience over the last two weeks. We have many days and weeks ahead and your health and the health of your loved ones are the first priority.
text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm

It has been two weeks since Governor Brown’s order to cancel large gatherings to limit the spread of the COVID-19 virus. Since that time, we have experienced a school cancelation through March 31, and last week the cancelation was extended through April 28.

Our staff will be returning to work beginning on March 30. Most of our staff will be working remotely and the few employees who do come in the buildings will follow strict social distancing guidelines. Our staff will be putting together supplemental learning materials for students. These materials will be available to families beginning April 6. The goal is to provide students and families with some easy-to-implement activities to prevent regression and learning loss during an extended break. If you haven’t already, please take the time to fill our Home Technology Survey. This survey will help the district determine how best to provide educational support resources to our families.

In the coming days, we expect to receive information from the Oregon Department of Education about graduation requirements for seniors and we will relay this information to our seniors and families as soon as we can.

We will continue serving breakfast and lunch. Over the last two weeks, we’ve served 1,097 meals at Turner Elementary and 2,259 meals at Aumsville Elementary. Beginning March 30, we will be adding Cloverdale Elementary as a meal pickup location. Anyone ages 1-18 can pick up breakfast and lunch at any elementary school location from 12-12:30. Look for the orange tents outside of those schools, and there, you will find our staff handing out meals. Students no longer need to be present to receive a meal.

Finally, I want to encourage you to check our website where we’ve created a COVID-19 section (https://bit.ly/2WPFCXm). Here you will find resources for you and your student as well as regular updates from the district.

Thank you for your patience over the last two weeks. We have many days and weeks ahead and your health and the health of your loved ones are the first priority.

post_text:
Información en español: https://bit.ly/2QL34RI

As the spread of COVID-19 continues, it is more important than ever to stay vigilant with social distancing and good hygiene. Please continue to do your part to keep our community safe. The following are some updates for Cascade families.

Governor Kate Brown issued Executive Order 20-12, directing everyone in Oregon to stay at home to the maximum extent possible and adding to the list of businesses that will be temporarily closed to stem the spread of COVID-19 in Oregon. The order is effective immediately and remains in effect until ended by the governor.

What does this mean for Cascade families? Essential services that are still allowed include our curbside, meal pickup at Turner and Aumsville Elementary. We are serving breakfast and lunch to anyone ages 1-18 from 12-12:30 at both locations. Look for the orange tents outside of those schools, and there, you will find our staff handing out meals. Please remember that the Oregon Department of Education does require the child to be present to receive a meal.

We will be sending out a survey to our families by Wednesday afternoon to find out more about your home technology resources. Please check your email for this survey. We will use this information to assess options and evaluate how to provide supplemental educational resources to our students. Turner families, this survey was already sent home to you, so you will not receive that email this week. This survey will also be available on our website.

Next week, our staff will be putting together supplemental education plans for students which will be available beginning April 6. Supplemental plans may include both packet and online resources for students. The goal is to provide students and families with some easy-to-implement activities to prevent regression and learning loss during an extended break.

To our senior class, we recognize that this global pandemic is disrupting your final months of high school. We are so sorry—it feels sad and unfair that events and milestones you have worked so hard for and were looking forward to are being postponed, canceled, or not celebrated in a group setting. We are actively working with the Oregon Department of Education to determine what needs to be done to help you complete your diploma requirements and they are very close to providing us with guidelines. We will keep you informed as we learn more. Our priority is helping you reach your goals for graduation, and we will get through this together.

Stay safe, stay healthy.

Good evening Cascade families,

We know it has been a long week! Thank you for your support and understanding as we all navigate this global health pandemic. We are doing our best to provide you with the latest information and resources that are available. We also know you have a lot of questions. Keep them coming. We hear you. We are all adjusting to this new reality. We are working with our leaders, the Oregon Dept. of Education, Oregon Health Authority and other partners to provide the information you need right now.

This morning, our district administrative team met to talk about our supplemental education plan and here’s what you can expect from us. Next week, we will send out a survey to find out more about your home technology resources. We will use this information to assess options and evaluate how to provide supplemental educational resources to our students. Turner families, this survey was already sent home to you, so you will not receive an email next week. This survey will also be available on our website.

This situation is ever-changing and we are continuing to plan as more guidance and mandates become available. Thank you for your patience during this unprecedented time.

Sincerely,

Darin Drill, Cascade School District Superintendent

post_text:
On March 17, Oregon Governor Kate Brown announced an extension of the statewide school closure to help prevent the spread of coronavirus COVID-19. The Governor’s new order means that schools will be closed for students for six weeks, through April 28, unless the closure is extended or lifted by order of the Governor before that date.

We are continuing to serve free meals through April 28 including spring break. Beginning next week, these meals will also include a grab-and-go breakfast for the following morning. Any child ages 1-18 can pick up food from 12-12:30 at Aumsville or Turner Elementary. Please note, at this time, the child must be present to receive a meal.

Our district administrative team is working on a supplemental education plan to be available to families on April 6. Each school principal will be reaching out to their families with more information in the next 24 hours.

This is a situation that is changing hourly and we are doing all we can to prepare for its challenges. So that we may continue to keep you informed, we will be sending out a lot of important updates over the next few weeks via email, social media or robocalls. All of these updates will be posted to our website as well.

We know that this is a trying time and that the closure of our schools is a tremendous challenge for families. Please stick with us as we navigate this unpredictable and difficult situation and we thank you for your cooperation and patience.

post_text:
Last night, Oregon Governor Kate Brown announced new guidance regarding group gatherings and social distancing. At this time, schools will remain open, but the suspension of non-essential school-based activities will begin immediately and remain in effect for 30 days. At this time, there are no known cases of the Coronavirus among Cascade students or staff members.

The Cascade School District is suspending all school-based assemblies and events, off-campus field trips, after-school activities, and professional development meetings and events.

With regard to athletics, we are continuing with spring practices. We are awaiting guidelines from OSAA with regard to spring contests. Winter sports banquets and spring sports parent meetings are postponed at this time. They will be rescheduled for a later date.

Please keep in mind this situation is ever-changing. We are working with state and county officials and will continue to update our status as new guidance emerges. To be clear, we are taking every step possible so that we can continue to provide high-quality education for all of our students and keep our schools open.

Thank you for your patience during this time.

More information is available on the district website: http://bit.ly/csdcovid19

post_text:
This past Spring, the Oregon state legislature passed the Student Success Act which will bring more funding to our district beginning in the 2020-2021 school year. This funding can be used to make improvements in class size, well-rounded education, instructional time, and/or health and safety. The district is now seeking input from our parents and the school community on how to prioritize these funds.

This video below includes the Student Success Presentation by Superintendent Darin Drill. In it, he discusses the different areas in which we can spend the money. After watching this video, please consider participating in the survey, linked below.

La primavera pasada, nuestra legislatura estatal aprobó la Ley de Éxito Estudiantil que traerá más fondos a nuestro distrito a partir del año escolar 2020-2021. Este dinero solo se puede utilizar para satisfacer las necesidades de salud mental o conductual de los estudiantes y aumentar el rendimiento académico de los estudiantes al tiempo que reducen las disparidades académicas. El Distrito Escolar de Cascade será buscando la opinión de nuestros padres y la comunidad escolar sobre cómo priorizar estos fondos. Necesitamos SU voz para ayudarnos a determinar cómo utilizar el dinero que recibiremos en el 2020-21.

Survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/YGR9YMS
La Encuesta: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/YGR9YMS?lang=es

https://youtu.be/NNXJazVVYa8

Cascade High School
February 11 at 2:46 PM ·

ATTENTION PARENTS AND ALL JUNIORS AND SENIORS...the Career Wheel is BACK! We had one for staff and now it is your turn! This Thursday Juniors 9-10 and Seniors 10-11 will have an opportunity to speak with over 60 folks from ALL career strands from lineman to restaurant owner to mortgage broker! You will have ten minutes to truly learn and receive advice about YOUR FUTURE. Please be on time and dress appropriately. Some businesses, like Amazon, are always looking for potential employees and will be there! This is for you so you can make a living for yourself and your family. BE THERE. Questions? Email Lisa Iverson liverson@cascade.k12.or.us THIS IS A CAN'T MISS!!!!!

Cascade softball clinics begin next month for any interested K-8 softball players. Clinic dates are February 9th, 16th, 23th & March 1st, 2020. 1-3pm each day. Each day of camp will include hitting and a specific fielding skill. The camp will be held in the High School's old gym.

The cost is $25 a day or $75 for all four sessions. Scholarships are available and registration is available at the door as well.

If you are interested in this camp, download and fill out the form below.

Form: http://bit.ly/csddball

post_text:
Our first community forum is tonight at 6:30 in the Aumsville 3-5 library. This forum is to discuss the Student Success Act and we need input from our parents on how to prioritize new funds coming to the district. Hope to see you tonight!

If you can't make it tonight, we will have a second forum on February 5th at 6:30 pm at Turner Elementary.
shared_text:
Cascade School District
December 27, 2019 at 11:00 PM ·

This past Spring, the Oregon state legislature passed the Student Success Act which will bring more funding to our district beginning in the 2020-2021 school year. This funding can be used to make improvements in class size, well-rounded education, instructional time, and/or health and safety. Cascade School District will be seeking input from our parents and the school community on how to prioritize these funds.

We will be holding two community forums to discuss these funds. The first forum will be at Aumsville Elementary on January 27th at 6:30 pm. The second will be held at Turner Elementary on February 5th at 6:30 pm. After each forum, we will ask you to participate in a brief survey to provide input and additional feedback. If you are unable to attend either forum, we will provide a video explaining the Student Success Act and the survey will be available online after the second community forum.

post_text: Graduation rates were released across Oregon. In 2018-19, our grad rate was 90%, compared to the state average 80%. Cascade High School is tied for 9th out of 355 schools with a 94% graduation rate. Congratulations Cascade students and staff!

post_text:
Volunteer opportunity for anyone interested in helping with this year's Cow Pie Classic.

There's a planning meeting on February 26th at 3:30 pm in the junior high library.
shared_text:
Cascade Junior High School
January 24 at 10:45 PM ·

Volunteers Needed!

Cascade Junior High is planning to hold our annual Cow Pie Classic on April 25, 2020! It is a fun run for pre-school students through 8th grade! We hold a 500 yard - Calf Race, and then 1K, 2K, and 3K running events. It is a great morning of exercise and community!

This year, we are looking for volunteers who would like to help us plan this great event! If you are interested, we are holding a planning meeting on February 26th at 3:30pm at the Cascade Junior High School library!

We would love it if you came and joined us to participate in the development of this positive event!

post_text:
This past Spring, the Oregon state legislature passed the Student Success Act which will bring more funding to our district beginning in the 2020-2021 school year. This funding can be used to make improvements in class size, well-rounded education, instructional time, and/or health and safety. Cascade School District will be seeking input from our parents and the school community on how to prioritize these funds.

We will be holding two community forums to discuss these funds. The first forum will be at Aumsville Elementary on January 27th at 6:30 pm. The second will be held at Turner Elementary on February 5th at 6:30 pm. After each forum, we will ask you to participate in a brief survey to provide input and additional feedback. If you are unable to attend either forum, we will provide a video explaining the Student Success Act and the survey will be available online after the second community forum.

Cascade Food & Toiletry Drive

Please join us in our efforts to bless our fellow community members this holiday season. If you are able to help, please bring items to Cascade Junior High School or Cascade High School by December 18th!

The following items are still needed for our annual food drive:

FRESH or FROZEN: turkey, ham

CANNED or BOXED FOODS: yams, potatoes, cake mix, tuna, gravy, soup, spaghetti noodles, spaghetti sauce, jam or jelly, stuffing, frosting, mac & cheese, corn, peanut butter, chili, canned fruit, cranberries, beans, biscuit mix, hamburger helper

TOILETRIES:soap, shampoo, conditioner, toilet paper, deodorant

post_text: Well deserved. There's a lot of history in our wrestling room and Tom Phillips is a big part of that!
shared_text:
Cascade High School
December 11, 2019 at 3:24 PM ·

Yesterday we officially deemed our wrestling room the "Tom Phillips Wrestling Room." Mr. Phillips was a longtime teacher, administrator, and coach at both the high school and junior high school. He coached the wrestling team from 1976 to 2006 (and stayed on as an assistant during the 2006-07 season.)

Thank you to everyone who made yesterday's event possible and congratulations Mr. Phillips.

If you are interested in this camp, download and fill out the form below.

post_text: What a cool way to recognize service members and give students a chance to learn more about the military! Thank you everyone who participated and made this event possible.
shared_text:
Cascade High School
November 14, 2019 at 8:36 PM ·

Yesterday, Cascade High School held its first Veterans Appreciation luncheon. Current and former military members spent first, second and third period with our students.

Students were divided into mall groups giving our students and visitors a chance for conversation.

After third period, the veterans and high school staff enjoyed a meal together in the cafeteria. Our manufacturing classes made beautiful metal flags to give to each of our guests.

Thank you to everyone who made this even possible including: Ursula Bischoff, Mike Sowles, Lisa Iverson, John Iverson, Dawn Brandtjen, Alexandria Greenwell, Justin Lowde, Tom Ptacek, Tim Ganfield, Tyler Woodrall, Matt Thatcher, David Schletty, David Medlock, Matt McBeth, Deb Bellmore, Tina and Robin and all our students for being so respectful towards our visitors.

It was a wonderful event and one we hope to make even bigger in the years to come.

Turner Trail Tuesday

Saturday is the day! Join the Cascade community from 9-11 to celebrate the opening ceremony for the Turner Trail. The trail starts at the Burkland Pool/Turner Elementary and is a 1.2 mile loop through town.

The event is FREE, just show up and enjoy the trail. There will be on-site experts discussing local nature, demonstrations by Cascade High School students, a scavenger hunt, food, freebies and more!! Fun for all ages!

This is event is open to the ENTIRE CASCADE COMMUNITY!

One of the goals of the new Turner Trail is to share information about local history and local nature! The beautiful trail markers feature information about plants and animals that you can find right in your own backyards.

If you want to learn more about local nature, be sure to come explore the new Turner Trail on October 26th from 9-11am. The event is FREE, just show up and enjoy the trail. There will be on-site experts and interactive activities. Fun for kids of all ages!

This is event is open to the ENTIRE CASCADE COMMUNITY!

post_text:
Part of our mission statement at Cascade is preparing students to be "career ready."

This morning, our high school staff participated in a career wheel where 13 different professionals visited with each staff member. Staff learned how to better integrate career-readiness into their classrooms to prepare students for life after high school and how to better advise students who are interested in a particular career field.

post_text: German students are coming to Cascade High School and we are looking for a few more host families.
shared_text:
Cascade High School
September 18, 2019 at 6:51 PM ·

We are looking for a few more host families!

German students will be coming to Cascade High School October 11th through November 1st and they need host families from our community to show them typical family life and American hospitality. Will your family open your home to host one of these great students for the 3 weeks they are here? It's so much fun and so easy!

Contact Mr. Thatcher (mthatcher@cascade.k12.or.us) or Mrs. Maben (jmaben@cascade.k12.or.us) for more information. This is open to anyone in the community, not just Cascade High School families, so please feel free to share this with your friends and family in the community.

post_text:
Bus Routes

Bus routes and stop times are available on our website: http://www.cascade.k12.or.us/departments/transportation

Click "Bus Routes and Stop Times" to find your student's stop and the approximate time the school bus should arrive.

Bus routes can be found in the Parent Portal. After you login, there is a menu on the left side. Click on "Student Information" then "Student Details." Toward the top of the page on the left, it will say "Bus" and have one or two numbers. If there is only one number, your child rides the same bus both to school and back home. If there are two numbers, the first number is their morning route number and the second number is their afternoon route number. If there is no number and your child is riding a bus, you will need to contact our transportation provider as they are not expecting your child to ride. Contact information is on the link provided above.

Please note these are route numbers NOT bus numbers. We do not go by bus numbers as they can changes depending on repairing and use for other trips (field trips and athletics).

post_text: Most of our kids will start school next Tuesday. Please watch for kids walking and biking along the road and school buses picking up our students. Thanks for keeping the roads safe for all!!
shared_text:
Marion County Sheriff's Office
August 27, 2019 at 11:57 PM ·

With school kicking off throughout Marion County next week, we want to remind everyone to watch out for kids at bus stops in the morning and afternoon hours. As a friendly reminder, it is illegal to pass a school bus when the red lights are flashing. Both directions of traffic must stop (even on a wide road like Lancaster Dr) unless the road is physically divided. Failure to stop for bus safety lights carries a presumptive fine of $440 and may cost you up to $2,000.

post_text:
SPORTS PHYSICALS

Cascade will be offering sports physicals for athletes for the 2019-20 school year. The physicals are scheduled for Thursday, August 8, 2019 from 4:00 pm to 7:00 pm in the Main Gym at Cascade High School. No appointment is necessary.

The physicals are $10 per athlete. The physicals will be performed by the Aumsville Medical Clinic and the PT Northwest staff. Students are required to have a physical every two years. The physicals must be on file at the school before a student-athlete can begin practice.

post_text: Congratulations Ms. Greenwell!!!
shared_text:
Oregon Alumni Band
July 22, 2019 at 4:10 PM ·

Allie Greenwell ('12), DOB for Cascade School District is this week's #MusicEducatorMonday Feature!

Favorite OMB memory
My favorite memory (though it didn’t seem great at the time) will always be Dr. Wiltshire sitting me down my freshman year when I wanted to quit and convincing me to stay in the band. I wanted to be a member of the Oregon Marching Band from the time I was a freshman in high school, and it was my dream to be drum major someday, but I was miserable and homesick during that first month. The moral I took from our discussion was that if I leave, I close the door to any future adventures, friendships, and leadership positions in the band. Quitting just means the end, while staying would only mean possibilities.

What lesson did you take from OMB that still applies to your life?
I think the lesson that has influenced me in my life and career the most is that leadership is service. As drum major, a teacher, etc. - it’s not about you. Being a leader isn’t about the glory or credit or receiving thanks. It’s about giving back to your band members (students) and being there for them when they need help, teaching, setting the example, and doing whatever you can behind the scenes so that anyone “under” you has a good time, learns things, and is comfortable. As a teacher,

What 2 pieces of advice would you give to a current student interested in pursuing a similar career?
You are going to be a great teacher. I didn’t hear those words enough as a student and I doubted myself well into starting my career, but if you believe it, you will be it. I’m telling you now that if you want this and you know that you will be great, you can do it. Take all of those lessons and values that you were taught which inspired you to be a part of this profession and wear them as a cape like the superhero that you WILL be.

Also... it gets better. Whenever you feel down, exhausted, not good enough, whatever - just repeat after me: It. Gets. Better.

post_text: Thank you STAND (Stand Tough Against Negligent Driving) for this afternoon's demonstration. We hope everyone will make good decisions behind the wheel.
shared_text:
Cascade High School
April 17, 2019 at 10:17 PM ·

This afternoon we created a drunk driving accident simulation. With the help of Life Flight, Turner Fire, the Marion County Sheriff Department, CCTV, and our incredible drama department, we were able to recreate the scene of a car crash. We would like to thank the STAND(stand tough against negligent driving) organization for their help in organizing this event. There is a full length live video recording archived on the Cascade High School Instagram page in addition to these pictures. Please drive safely and make good decisions!
text:
Thank you STAND (Stand Tough Against Negligent Driving) for this afternoon's demonstration. We hope everyone will make good decisions behind the wheel.

We would like to thank the STAND(stand tough against negligent driving) organization for their help in organizing this event. There is a full length live video recording archived on the Cascade High School Instagram page in addition to these pictures. Please drive safely and make good decisions!

Driver Education Class Sign-Ups

Attention parents of new drivers---Dates for Driver Education 2019-2020 have been set. We are planning for a class in the Fall- September 10th through mid-October. Sign up soon as spots fill up fast (We already have several students signed up for the Fall class!). Complete the application and get it to Mr. McBeth at the High School room 5 to reserve your spot. Mr. McBeth can be reached at 503-749-8020 x2005

post_text: Congratulations to Mr. Clark and the members of the Cascadians!!!
shared_text:
Cascadians Choir
March 22, 2019 at 4:57 AM ·

We had the opportunity to go to Districts on Wednesday and were able to practice at a beautiful church before! We did a fantastic job, with the Cascadians Choir qualifying for state for the first time in our school's history! While the term did not begin exactly positively, with various singers missing from our choir, we connected with each other and to the music which had a very positive outcome! Congratulations Cascadians!
text:
Congratulations to Mr. Clark and the members of the Cascadians!!!

We did a fantastic job, with the Cascadians Choir qualifying for state for the first time in our school's history! shared_text:
Cascade Junior High School
March 22, 2019 at 6:03 PM ·

FRESHMAN ORIENTATION INFORMATION NIGHT

Freshman orientation information night will be held on April 4, 2019 at 6:30 pm in the Cascade High School Auditorium. All incoming freshman and their parents are encouraged to attend this information meeting to have a better understanding of how to successfully transition into the high school. Incoming freshman who attend this meeting will be able to have first choice on electives! There will also be a raffle! Other discussion topics will include graduation requirements, classes, clubs and activities, AVID, and all the great things that Cascade High School has to offer. We will answer your questions and looking forward to meeting with you and your student.

post_text:
TIME TO SPRING FORWARD!!!

This Sunday morning is the beginning of Daylight Saving Time. That means it is time to “spring forward.”

Remember before you go to bed Saturday night (March 9th) or at 2:00 am on Sunday, March 10th, set your clocks FORWARD ONE HOUR. If you forget, you will be late to everything.

It is also a reminder to check/change the batteries in your home’s smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors.

post_text: From Marion County Sheriff's Office
shared_text:
Marion County Sheriff's Office
February 1, 2019 at 2:50 PM ·

Last night in coordination with the Cascade School District, Aumsville and Turner Police Departments, deputies identified a 13 year old juvenile as the person responsible for making a threat directed at Cascade Middle School via social media. The juvenile was determined to have no access to any weapons and stated the post was a "joke".

Deputies are working closely with the parents of the child to include referring the charge of disorderly conduct to the Marion County Juvenile Department. The Sheriff's Office understands how stressful these types of incidents can be to our community. To help ease this stress deputies and officers from Aumsville and Turner will have a presence on the Cascade campus throughout the day.

The Sheriff's Office would like to thank all of our community partners for helping us identify the person responsible quickly. This incident is an example that can be used by parents to educate their children that, no threat is a joke. The Sheriff's Office encourages all parents to monitor your child's social media accounts closely to ensure they are not engaging in behavior that could have life altering effects.
text:
From Marion County Sheriff's Office

Marion County Sheriff's Office
February 1, 2019 at 2:50 PM ·

Last night in coordination with the Cascade School District, Aumsville and Turner Police Departments, deputies identified a 13 year old juvenile as the person responsible for making a threat directed at Cascade Middle School via social media. The juvenile was determined to have no access to any weapons and stated the post was a "joke".

Deputies are working closely with the parents of the child to include referring the charge of disorderly conduct to the Marion County Juvenile Department. The Sheriff's Office understands how stressful these types of incidents can be to our community. To help ease this stress deputies and officers from Aumsville and Turner will have a presence on the Cascade campus throughout the day.

The Sheriff's Office would like to thank all of our community partners for helping us identify the person responsible quickly. This incident is an example that can be used by parents to educate their children that, no threat is a joke. The Sheriff's Office encourages all parents to monitor your child's social media accounts closely to ensure they are not engaging in behavior that could have life altering effects.

post_text:
SOCIAL MEDIA POST UPDATE

Last night, Thursday, January 31, 2019, it was reported to law enforcement that a student made a threatening statement against Cascade Junior High regarding Friday, February 1, 2019. Law enforcement officials went quickly to work, and early this morning they identified the individual who made the comments. That individual is being dealt with by both law enforcement and Cascade school officials.

Today, school at Cascade Junior High will run normally. We will have a law enforcement presence to alleviate fears and concerns. We can say that the threat made via social media last night no longer exists. We want to thank Turner Police, Aumsville Police and Marion County Sheriff's Department for running this effective and efficient investigation and supporting us today.
text:
SOCIAL MEDIA POST UPDATE

Last night, Thursday, January 31, 2019, it was reported to law enforcement that a student made a threatening statement against Cascade Junior High regarding Friday, February 1, 2019. Law enforcement officials went quickly to work, and early this morning they identified the individual who made the comments. That individual is being dealt with by both law enforcement and Cascade school officials.

Today, school at Cascade Junior High will run normally. We will have a law enforcement presence to alleviate fears and concerns. We can say that the threat made via social media last night no longer exists. We want to thank Turner Police, Aumsville Police and Marion County Sheriff's Department for running this effective and efficient investigation and supporting us today.

post_text:
VETERANS DAY

In observance of Veterans Day, all schools and offices of the Cascade School District will be closed on Monday, November 12, 2018. We will re-open on Tuesday, November 13th. We hope you have a safe holiday weekend.

We would like to thank our veterans who have served us in the past. We also thank those who are currently serving in our armed forces and appreciate the families who are here at home. Thank you all for your service, and we pause to honor your service!

We would like to thank our veterans who have served us in the past. We also thank those who are currently serving in our armed forces and appreciate the families who are here at home. Thank you all for your service, and we pause to honor your service!

TIME TO FALL BACK TONIGHT!!!

Daylight Saving Time ends TONIGHT. It is time to “fall back.”

Remember before you go to bed tonight set your clocks BACK ONE HOUR. If you are a night owl, the official end time is tomorrow morning at 2:00 a.m.

It is a great time to check and change the batteries in your smoke alarms and your carbon monoxide detectors.

post_text:
TIME TO FALL BACK!!!

It is that time of year to reset your clocks. Daylight Saving Time ends. It is time to “fall back.”

Remember before you go to bed Saturday night (November 3rd) or at 2:00 am on Sunday, November 4th, set your clocks BACK ONE HOUR. Should you forget, you will just be an hour early to everything.

Also, it is a great time to check/change the batteries in your smoke alarms and your carbon monoxide detectors.

5th/6th GRADE BASKETBALL

Cascade Youth Basketball, a civic basketball group that serves our area, would like to remind you about the mandatory 5th-6th grade player evaluation THIS SATURDAY, October 20th. Girls are at 3:00pm and boys are at 4:30pm in the junior high gym. Please have your registration form complete if you haven't already mailed it to us. If for some reason your child will not attend we must have their registration in so they can be drafted. Forms can be found on our website (link below) and at every school office in the district.

https://www.cascadeyouthbasketball.org

post_text:
SPORTS PHYSICALS AT CASCADE

Cascade School District is once again holding its annual sports physical clinic for our student-athletes. If your child will be playing a school-sponsored sport during the 2018-19 school year, your child is REQUIRED to have a physical on file with the school that is less than two years old. This applies to both high school students AND junior high students.

The clinic will be held on Thursday, August 9, 2018 from 4:00pm to 6:30pm in the high school main gymnasium. It is for students entering grades 6 through 12. The cost of the clinic is $10 per athlete and payment is made to Aumsville Medical Clinic.

Forms are available at the clinic or you can use this link: https://cascadeseniorhighschoolor.bigteams.com/library/files/demo883.bigteamsdemo_com_851/files/Physical%20form%202017-18.pdf

Part 1 is filled out by the student and parent. Parent/guardian signature is required for this part. This side MUST be completely filled out and signed BEFORE the student can go through the physical examination with the medical providers.

If you have any questions, please contact the Athletic Department at 503-749-8020 option #6.

CASCADESENIORHIGHSCHOOLOR.BIGTEAMS.COM

CASCADESENIORHIGHSCHOOLOR.BIGTEAMS.COM
cascadeseniorhighschoolor.bigteams.com

post_text:
SPORTS PHYSICALS

Cascade will be offering sports physicals for athletes for the 2018-19 school year. The physicals are scheduled for Thursday, August 9, 2018 from 4:30 pm to 6:00 pm in the Main Gym at Cascade High School. No appointment is necessary.

The physicals are only $10 per athlete. The physicals will be performed by the Aumsville Medical Clinic and the PT Northwest staff. Students are required to have a physical every two years. The physicals must by on file at the school before a student-athlete can begin practice.

If you have any questions about the physicals, please call the high school at the number below. If you are not sure if your child will be due for a physical, you can call the school office. Please feel free to leave a message on voicemail. Calls will be returned when staff returns to work.
Cascade High School at 503-749-8020 (option 6)
Cascade Junior High School at 503-749-8030 (option 1)

OSAA Physical Form (Part 1 can be filled out and signed before the day of the physicals):
https://cascadeseniorhighschoolor.bigteams.com/library/files/demo883.bigteamsdemo_com_851/files/Physical%20form%202017-18.pdf

CELEBRATION OF LIFE

Cascade lost one of its own on June 12, 2018. Zach was a great staff member. As one of our maintenance workers, he was known by many throughout the schools of Cascade. He offered help to anyone who asked including our band and wrestling programs. We will miss him dearly. We will be celebrating his life on Saturday, June 30, 2018 at 2:00 pm in the Cascade High School Auditorium. Below is a link to his obituary.

REGULAR BOARD MEETING NOTICE:

The Cascade School District, Turner, Oregon, will hold a Board of Education regular meeting at 6:00 p.m. in the District Office Board Room located at 10226 Marion Rd. SE, Turner, Oregon, 97392 on Monday, June 11, 2018. During the first hour, an executive session will be held in accordance with ORS 192.660 (2)(b) to hear a personnel complaint and is closed to the public. The regular board meeting will begin at 7:00 p.m.

Items to be considered: Executive Session per ORS 192.660 (2)(b) to hear personnel complaint, Personnel, 2018-19 budget adoption, AVID Newsletter–Cougar Connection, Overnight trip requests (baseball and football), Board meeting June 25, 2018, July board meeting date

post_text:
FROM TURNER ELEMENTARY

A huge thank you to Representative Denyc Boles, our local District 19 House Representative, for securing a pallet of water for the students and staff at Turner Elementary from Home Depot (north). Representative Boles worked with Cascade graduate and Home Depot employee, Jason Dudash, to get this donation. Additionally, Turner City Manager David Sawyer made sure we had enough water to get through yesterday. At Turner Elementary we are making sure all students and staff have access to water bottles and really appreciate all the support.

--Mr. Petersen

post_text:
WATER AT TURNER ELEMENTARY

The City of Turner gets its drinking water from the City of Salem. Late Tuesday afternoon, we received notice that due to algae blooms in the Detroit reservoir the City of Salem’s water should not be consumed by children ages 5 and under. At the direction of the Oregon Health Authority, this applies to children age 5 and under as well as anyone who is pregnant, nursing, receiving dialysis, or immunocompromised.

In an effort to be overly cautious, we will not be allowing any students or staff to drink the water at Turner Elementary until the city verifies our water is clean again. Additionally, school meals will be prepared with bottled water. We have bottled water at school.

MEMORIAL DAY HOLIDAY

In observance of Memorial Day, all schools and offices of the Cascade School District will be closed on Monday, May 28, 2018. We will resume regular schedules on Tuesday, May 29, 2018. We hope the extended weekend is a happy and safe one for all of our staff, students, and community.

We also extend our appreciation to those who gave the ultimate for our country. We thank you and recognize your patriotic service!

If you are not familiar with late start Wednesdays, schools throughout the Cascade School District will start two hours later than their regular times.

CASCADE STAYS IN 4A CLASSIFICATION

After two appeals, the final decision has been made that Cascade High School will remain in the 4A classification and will return next school year to the Oregon West Conference. This is the same classification and conference that Cascade is in at the current time.

SPRING CARNIVAL TONIGHT!!!

Family fun is planned for tonight at the Cloverdale Spring Carnival. Dinner is available from The Spud Bus and Kona Ice food trucks beginning at 5:30 pm. Games and activities are from 6-8pm with tickets being sold for .50 each.

There will be lots of activities and raffle tickets available. We will also have silent auction baskets and other great auction items.

We hope to see you there for this fun evening. If you have any questions or would like to help, please call or text Stephanie Bromley at 503-428-7373 or Tori Reul at 503-881-2746 or email cloverdalepto@yahoo.com.

Thank you to the many business sponsors!
